On Tuesday 21 August 2001 07:03, Parag Shetye wrote:

IMHO this looks like you are doing too many things at the same time.

> public void testCreateBatchLabelNoInnerClass() {
>
>    try {
>       BatchLabel aBatchLabel = new BatchLabel(
>          "20010530",  "A13",  "1" );
This first argument seems to be some kind of date, why don't you use a 
date class?
You could then test that date class in isolation (or use Java's Date 
class and rely on it working) and skip everything that is on date 
checking in the tests for labels.

>       assert ( aBatchLabel.getBatchLabel().equals(
>          "A13-1 EXP. 05/01" ) ) ;
If  "EXP" is a fix string I would have just one test showing "EXP" is 
properly inserted.

>    } catch (Exception e) {
>       assert ( "Exception:" + e, false );
Why do you catch the exception just to fail?
Have JUnit catch it for you.

Now all that's left is the last two arguments. You could wrap them in 
anoher object that accepts in its constructor one or two arguments and 
creates the label part from them.
Again this new object could be tested in isolation.

Hope this helps,

Robert
subject: Re: [junit] A Growing Problem
